page.title: 6.1.0: Lesson Overview
page.contents:
In this lesson, you will review what you have learned about polynomials to classify them into like terms to solve addition and subtraction problems. You will solve addition and subtraction problems using polynomial functions. You will be able to check your work by evaluating these functions and solutions for given values.

Polynomials are frequently used in calculating physics problems and other real-world situations involving projectiles and the motion of objects. Mastering the polynomial operations in this unit will help you in future studies.

When you finish this lesson, you will be able to:

  • Determine the degree of polynomials.
  • Add and subtract polynomials.
  • Evaluate a polynomial function for a given value.
  • Add and subtract polynomial functions.

Here are the activities that will help you reach those goals:

  • 6.1.1: Understanding Polynomials
  • 6.1.2: Adding and Subtracting Polynomials
    • 6.1.2: Self Check
    • 6.1.2: Additional Resources
  • 6.1.3: Evaluating a Polynomial Function for a Given Value
    • 6.1.3: Self Check
    • 6.1.3: Additional Resources
  • 6.1.4: Adding and Subtracting Polynomial Functions
    • 6.1.4: Self Check
    • 6.1.4: Additional Resources
  • 6.1.5: Reviewing Polynomial Addition and Subtraction

After that, you’ll practice and review.

  • 6.1.6: Practice
  • 6.1.7: Lesson Summary

page.title: 6.1.1: Understanding Polynomials
page.contents:
Activity

A monomial is an algebraic expression with exactly one term: \(5x^2\)

A binomial is an algebraic expression with exactly two terms: \(5x^2 + 6y^3\)

A trinomial is an algebraic expression with exactly three terms: \(5x^2 + 6y^3 - 7c\)

Monomials, binomials, and trinomials are all different types of polynomials. A polynomial is a monomial or two or more monomials combined by addition or subtraction.

Working with your partner, use the following Desmos activity to sort the polynomials below. Then enter your answers below to check your understanding.

Polynomial Sort by Type

\(x^2\)

\(c + 4\)

\(mn\)

\(8d^2 + 3e - g\)

\(b - h\)

\(15\)

\(n^2 - 7f + ab\)

\(z\)


  1. Which of the polynomials are monomials?

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

\(x^2\), \(15\), \(z\), \(mn\)



  1. Which of the polynomials are binomials?

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

\(c + 4\), \(b - h\)



  1. Which of the polynomials are trinomials?

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

\(8d^2 + 3e - g\), \(n^2 - 7f + ab\)


The degree of a polynomial is the highest degree of all its terms.

Working with your partner, use the following Desmos activity to sort the same polynomials by degree. Then enter your answers below to check your understanding.

Polynomial Sort by Degree


  1. Which of the polynomials have a degree of 0?

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

\(15\)



  1. Which of the polynomials have a degree of 1?

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

\(c + 4\), \(b - h\), \(z\), \(mn\)



  1. Which of the polynomials have a degree of 2?

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

\(x^2\), \(8d^2 + 3e - g\), \(n^2 - 7f + ab\)

page.title: 6.1.2: Adding and Subtracting Polynomials
page.contents:
Activity

We will solve these two problems as a class.


  1. Do these terms have the same variables with the same exponents? Explain your answer.

    \(6x^4y^2\)         \(8x^4y^2\)

Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

Yes. Both terms have the same variables raised to the same degrees: \(x\) is raised to the fourth power, and \(y\) is squared.



  1. Add the terms together: \(6x^4y^2+8x^4y^2\). What is the sum?

Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

\(14x^4y^2\)


Solve the following monomial addition and subtraction problems on your own.



  1. \(12q^2+9q^2\)

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

\(21q^2\)



  1. \(-14c^3+5c^3\)

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

\(-9c^3\)



  1. \(8g^2h^2+(-6g^2h^2)\)

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

\(2g^2h^2\)



  1. \(8mn^3p-(-5mn^3p)\)

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

\(13mn^3p\)



  1. \(-16a^2+3b^2+8a^2 \)

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

\(-8a^2+3b^2\)



  1. Can the following monomials be simplified using like terms? Explain.

    \(17a^2bc^3+6a^2b^2c^3\)

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

No, the monomial terms do not contain the same variables with the same exponents. The first term has the variable \(b\) with an exponent of 1. The second term has the variable \(b\) with an exponent of 2. The monomials are not like terms.


Solve the following polynomial addition and subtraction problems on your own.


  1. \((5k^2+7k-2)+(7k^2+9k-4)\)

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

\(12k^2+16k-6\)



  1. \((12w^2+w-11)-(5w^2+8w+6)\)

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

\(7w^2-7w-17\)



  1. \((9h^2-4h+17)+(2h^2-9)\)

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

\(11h^2-4h+8\)



  1. \((8f^2+6fv-3v^2)-(6f^2-3v^2)\)

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

\(2f^2+6fv\)



  1. \((8z^3-6zx+3x^2)+(12z^3-4zx)\)

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

\(20z^3-10zx+3x^2\)



Extending Your Thinking

Simplify.

\((6a^3-2a^2b)-2(ab^2+3b^3)+(2a^2b+2ab^2)\)

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

\(6a^3-6b^3\)

Here is how to solve this problem:
\((6a^3-2a^2b)-2(ab^2+3b^3)+(2a^2b+2ab^2)\)

Step 1
Distribute the multiplication over addition.
\(6a^3-2a^2b-2ab^2-6b^3+2a^2b+2ab^2\)

Step 2
Use the Commutative Property to rearrange like terms together.
\(6a^3-2a^2b+2a^2b-2ab^2+2ab^2-6b^3\)

Step 3
Combine like terms.
\(6a^3-6b^3\)

answer.response: That’s correct! Check yourself: By combining like terms, you can add the polynomials.
Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: You need to add the polynomials instead of subtracting them. The answer is \(17y^2+14y+1\).
Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: Check the constants that you added. The answer is \(17y^2+14y+1\).
Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: Check your addition on the terms to the second degree. The answer is \(17y^2+14y+1\).

answer.answer_text: I am not sure.

page.title: 6.1.2: Additional Resources
page.contents:
Adding and Subtracting Monomials

We have learned how to simplify expressions by combining like terms. Remember, like terms must have the same variables with the same exponent. Since monomials are terms, adding and subtracting monomials is the same as combining like terms. If the monomials are like terms, we just combine them by adding or subtracting the coefficients. Remember that like terms must have the same variables with the same exponents.

These terms have the same variables and the same exponents:

  • \(5m^3n^2\)          \(2m^3n^2\)

So we can add the monomials:

  • \(5m^3n^2 + 2m^3n^2 = 7m^3n^2\)

The variables and exponents of the monomials do not change when we add or subtract them.

Try It: Adding and Subtracting Monomials


Add or subtract.

  1. \( 25y^2+15y^2\)
  2. \(16pq^3-(-7pq^3)\)

Write down your answers. Then select the Solution button to compare your work.

Here is how to add and subtract:

Combine like terms to simplify the expressions.

  1. \( 25y^2+15y^2=40y^2\)
  1. \(\begin{array}{rcl}16pq^3-(-7pq^3)&=&16pq^3+7pq^3\\&=&23pq^3\end{array}\)

Adding and Subtracting Polynomials

We can think of adding and subtracting polynomials as just adding and subtracting a series of monomials. Look for the like terms—those with the same variables and the same exponent. The Commutative Property allows us to rearrange the terms to put like terms together.

Let’s look at an example.

Find the sum: \((7y^2-2y+9)+(4y^2-8y-7)\).

Step 1
Identify like terms by finding those with the same variable and same exponent.
\(({\style{color:red}7}{\style{color:red}y}^{\style{color:red}2} - {\style{color:blue}2}{\style{color:blue}y} + 9) + ({\style{color:red}4}{\style{color:red}y}^{\style{color:red}2} - {\style{color:blue}8}{\style{color:blue}y} - 7)\)

Step 2
Use the Commutative Property to rearrange like terms together. Be sure to take the appropriate sign with each term \((+/-)\).
\({\style{color:red}7}{\style{color:red}y}^{\style{color:red}2} + {\style{color:red}4}{\style{color:red}y}^{\style{color:red}2} - {\style{color:blue}2}{\style{color:blue}y} - {\style{color:blue}8}{\style{color:blue}y} + 9 - 7\)

Step 3
Combine like terms.
\({\style{color:red}1}{\style{color:red}1}{\style{color:red}y}^{\style{color:red}2} - {\style{color:blue}1}{\style{color:blue}0}{\style{color:blue}y} + 2\)


Try It: Adding and Subtracting Polynomials


Find the sum and difference. If necessary, be careful with the signs as you distribute while subtracting the polynomials.

  1. \((7x^2-4x+5)+(x^2-7x+3)\)
  2. \((9w^2-7w+5)-(2w^2-4)\)

Write down your answers. Then select the Solution button to compare your work.

Here is how to find the sum and difference:

  1. \((7x^2-4x+5)+(x^2-7x+3)=8x^2-11x+8\)

  2. \(\begin{array}{rcl}(9w^2-7w+5)-(2w^2-4)&=&(9w^2-7w+5)-2w^2+4\\&=&7w^2-7w+9\end{array}\)

answer.answer_text: I’d like to retry the self check.
I’m ready for the next activity.

page.title: 6.1.3: Evaluating a Polynomial Function for a Given Value
page.contents:
Activity

Evaluate each function for \(h(-4)\), \(h(0)\), and \(h(6)\).


  1. \(h(x) = 3x^2 - 7x - 9\)

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

\(h(-4) = 67\)
\(h(0) = -9\)
\(h(6) = 57\)



  1. \(h(x) =-4x^2 - 3x + 2\)

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

\(h(-4) = -50\)
\(h(0) = 2\)
\(h(6) = -160\)



  1. \(h(x) = -2x^2 - 5x +15\)

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

\(h(-4) = 3\)
\(h(0) = 15\)
\(h(6) = -87\)


Evaluate each function for \(d(-2)\), \(d(0)\), and \(d(3)\).


  1. \( d(x) = 8x^2 - 2x + 6\)

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

\(d(-2) = 42\)
\(d(0) = 6\)
\(d(3) = 72\)



  1. \(d(x) = -5x^2 - 4x + 10\)

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

\(d(-2) = -2\)
\(d(0) = 10\)
\(d(3) = -47\)



  1. \( d(x) = -3x^2 + 6x + 7\)

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

\(d(-2) = -17\)
\(d(0) = 7\)
\(d(3) = -2\)

Arrange into pairs. One partner should write their own polynomial function similar to the ones in this activity. The other partner should select 3 different values between –10 and 10. Exchange your function and values with your partner. Each member should evaluate the polynomial function for the given values. When finished, compare your answers. Did you find the same solutions? Discuss any differences you found.

page.title: 6.1.3: Self Check
page.contents: For the function \(g(x) = 5x^2 - 8x + 4\), find \(g(-3)\).

answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: When you squared –3 in the first term, did you get 9? The answer is \(g(-3) = 5(-3)^2 - 8(-3) + 4 = 5(9) + 24 + 4 = 73\).
Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: Did you square –3 in the first term? The answer is \(g(-3) = 5(-3)^2 - 8(-3) + 4 = 5(9) + 24 + 4 = 73\).
Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: Did you substitute –3 into the function? The answer is \(g(-3) = 5(-3)^2 - 8(-3) + 4 = 5(9) + 24 + 4 = 73\).
That’s correct! Check yourself: \(g(-3) = 5(-3)^2 - 8(-3) + 4 = 5(9) + 24 + 4 = 73\).

answer.answer_text: I am not sure.

page.title: 6.1.3: Additional Resources
page.contents:
Evaluating a Polynomial Function for a Given Value

A polynomial function is a function whose range values are defined by a polynomial. For example, \(f(x) = x^2 + 5x + 6\) and \(g(x) = 3x-4\) are polynomial functions because \(x^2 + 5x + 6\) and \(3x - 4\) are polynomials.

To evaluate a polynomial function, we will substitute the given value for the variable and then simplify using the order of operations.

Let’s look at some examples.

For the function \(f(x) = 5x^2 - 8x + 4\), find:

  1. \( f(4)\)
  2. \(f(-2)\)
  3. \(f(0)\)
  1. \(f(x)=5x^2-8x+4\)

Step 1
To find \(f(4)\), substitute \({\style{color:red}4}\) for \(x\).
\(f({\style{color:red}4})=5({\style{color:red}4})^2-8({\style{color:red}4})+4\)

Step 2
Simplify the exponents.
\(f(4)=5 \cdot 16-8(4)+4\)

Step 3
Multiply.
\(f(4)=80-32+4\)

Step 4
Simplify.
\(f(4)=52\)


  1. \(f(x)=5x^2-8x+4\)

Step 1
To find \(f(-2)\), substitute \({\style{color:red}-}{\style{color:red}2}\) for \(x\).
\(f({\style{color:red}-}{\style{color:red}2})=5({\style{color:red}-}{\style{color:red}2})^2-8({\style{color:red}-}{\style{color:red}2})+4\)

Step 2
Simplify the exponents.
\(f(-2)=5 \cdot 4-8(-2)+4\)

Step 3
Multiply.
\(f(-2)=20+15+4\)

Step 4
Simplify.
\(f(-2)=40\)


  1. \(f(x)=5x^2-8x+4\)

Step 1
To find \(f(0)\), substitute \({\style{color:red}0}\) for \(x\).
\(f({\style{color:red}0})=5({\style{color:red}0})^2-8({\style{color:red}0})+4\)

Step 2
Simplify the exponents.
\(f(0)=5 \cdot 0-8(0)+4\)

Step 3
Multiply.
\(f(0)=0+0+4\)

Step 4
Simplify.
\(f(0)=4\)


Try It: Evaluating a Polynomial Function for a Given Value


For the function \(f(x) = 3x^2 + 2x - 15\), find:

  1. \( f(3)\)
  2. \(f(-5) \)
  3. \(f(0) \)

Write down your answers. Then select the Solution button to compare your work.

Here is how to evaluate the polynomial function:

  1. \( f(x) = 3x^2 + 2x - 15 \)
    \(f(3) = 3(3)^2 + 2(3) - 15\)
    \(f(3) = 3(9) + 6 - 15\)
    \(f(3) = 18\)
  1. \( f(x) = 3x^2 + 2x - 15\)
    \(f(-5) = 3(-5)^2 + 2(-5) - 15\)
    \(f(-5) = 3(25) - 10 - 15\)
    \(f(-5) = 50\)
  1. \( f(x) = 3x^2 + 2x - 15\)
    \( f(0) = 3(0)^2 + 2(0) - 15\)
    \( f(0) = -15\)

answer.answer_text: I’d like to retry the self check.
I’m ready for the next activity.

page.title: 6.1.4: Adding and Subtracting Polynomial Functions
page.contents:
Activity

Add the polynomial functions. Evaluate the sum for each given value.

\(z(x) = 8x^2 + 4x - 6\)          \(w(x) = -5x^2 + 2x + 3\)


  1. \( (z + w)(x) = \) ___________

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

\((z + w)(x) = 3x^2 + 6x - 3\)



  1. \( (z + w)(6) = \) ___________

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

\((z + w)(6) = 141\)



  1. \((z + w)(-9) = \) ___________

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

\((z + w)(-9) = 186\)



  1. \((z + w)(0)\) = ___________

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

\((z + w)(0) = -3\)


Subtract the polynomial functions. Evaluate the sum for each given value.

\(m(x) = -6x^2 + 2x - 8\)          \(n(x) = -x^2 - 7x - 6\)


  1. \((m - n)(x) =\) ___________

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

\((m - n)(x) = -5x^2 + 9x - 2\)



  1. \((m - n)(-2) =\) ___________

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

\((m - n)(-2) = -40\)



  1. \( (m - n)(0) =\) ___________

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

\((m - n)(0) = -2\)



  1. \((m - n)(4) =\) ___________

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

\((m - n)(4) = -46\)



  1. What is a good way to check that you found the correct sum or difference when adding or subtracting polynomial functions?

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

Substitute a value for \(x\) into the individual polynomial functions. Add or subtract the results. The answer should be equal to the value you find when you substitute it into the sum or difference of the polynomial functions.


Video: Combining and Evaluating Polynomial Functions

Watch the following video to learn more about how to add and subtract polynomial functions and evaluate them at a given value:

answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: Check your operations when finding \((f+g)(x)\). The answer is \((f+g)(x) = 6x^2-x+7\) and \((f+g)(5) = 152\).
That’s correct! Check yourself: \((f+g)(x) = 5x^2-4x-1 + x^2+3x+8 = 6x^2-x+7\). Substitute 5 for \(x\) to find \((f+g)(5)\). \((f+g)(5) = 6(5)^2-(5)+7 = 150-5+7 = 152\).
Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: Did you find \((f-g)(x)\)? You need to find \((f+g)(x)\). The answer is \((f+g)(x) = 6x^2-x+7\) and \((f+g)(5) = 152\).
Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: Did you square 5 in the first term when finding \((f+g)(5)\)? The answer is \((f+g)(x) = 6x^2-x+7\) and \((f+g)(5) = 152\).

answer.answer_text: I am not sure.

page.title: 6.1.4: Additional Resources
page.contents:
Adding and Subtracting Polynomial Functions

Just as polynomials can be added and subtracted, polynomial functions can also be added and subtracted.


For functions \(f(x)\) and \(g(x)\),

  • \((f + g)(x) = f(x) + g(x)\)
  • \((f - g)(x) = f(x) - g(x)\)

Let’s look at some examples.

For the functions \(f(x) = 3x^2-5x+7\) and \(g(x) = x^2-4x-3\), find:

  1. \((f+g)(x)\)
  2. \( (f+g)(3) \)
  3. \( (f-g)(x) \)
  4. \( (f-g)(-2) \)
  1. (\(f+g)(x)=f(x)+g(x)\)

Step 1
Substitute \(f(x)={\style{color:red}3}{\style{color:red}x}^{\style{color:red}2}\;{\style{color:red}-}\;{\style{color:red}5}{\style{color:red}x}\;{\style{color:red}+}\;{\style{color:red}7}\) and \(g(x)={\style{color:blue}x}^{\style{color:blue}2}\;{\style{color:blue}-}\;{\style{color:blue}4}{\style{color:blue}x}\;{\style{color:blue}-}\;{\style{color:blue}3}\).
\((f+g)(x)=({\style{color:red}3}{\style{color:red}x}^{\style{color:red}2}\;{\style{color:red}-}\;{\style{color:red}5}{\style{color:red}x}\;{\style{color:red}+}\;{\style{color:red}7}){\style{color:blue}(}{\style{color:blue}x}^{\style{color:blue}2}\;{\style{color:blue}-}\;{\style{color:blue}4}{\style{color:blue}x}\;{\style{color:blue}-}\;{\style{color:blue}3}{\style{color:blue})}\)

Step 2
Rewrite without the parentheses.
\((f+g)(x)+3x^2-5x+7+x^2-4x+7-3\)

Step 3
Put like terms together.
\((f+g)(x)=3x^2+x^2-5x-4x+7-3\)

Step 4
Combine like terms.
\((f+g)(x)=4x^2-9x+4\)

In part (a), we found \((f+g)(x)\), and now are asked to find \((f+g)(3)\).


  1. \((f+g)(x)=4x^2-9x+4\)

Step 1
To find \((f+g)(3)\), substitute \(x=3\).
\((f+g)(3)=4(3)^2-9 \cdot 3+4\)

Step 2
Simplify.
\((f+g)(3)=4 \cdot 9-9 \cdot 3+ 4\)
\((f+g)(3)=36-27+4\)
\((f+g)(3)=13\)

Notice that we could have found \((f+g)(3)\) by first finding the values of \(f(3)\) and \(g(3)\) separately and then adding the results.

Step 1
Find \(f (3)\).
\(f(x)=3x^2-5x+7\)
\( f({\style{color:red}3})=3({\style{color:red}3})^2-5({\style{color:red}3})+7\)
\(f(3)=19\)

Step 2
Find \(g(3)\).
\(g(x)=x^2-4x-3\)
\(g(3)=-6\)

Step 3
Find \((f+g)(3)\).
\((f+g)(x)=f(x)+g(x)\)
\((f+g)(3)=f(3)+g(3)\)

Step 4
Substitute \(f(3)={\style{color:red}1}{\style{color:red}9}\) and \(g(3)= {\style{color:blue}-}{\style{color:blue}6}\).
\((f+g)(3)=19+(-6)\)
\((f+g)(3)=13\)


  1. \((f-g)(x)=f(x)-g(x)\)

Step 1
Substitute \(f(x)={\style{color:red}3}{\style{color:red}x}^{\style{color:red}2}\;{\style{color:red}-}\;{\style{color:red}5}{\style{color:red}x}\;{\style{color:red}+}\;{\style{color:red}7}\) and \(g(x)= {\style{color:blue}x}^{\style{color:blue}2}\;{\style{color:blue}-}\;{\style{color:blue}4}{\style{color:blue}x}\;{\style{color:blue}-}\;{\style{color:blue}3}\).
\((f-g)(x)=( {\style{color:red}3}{\style{color:red}x}^{\style{color:red}2}\;{\style{color:red}-}\;{\style{color:red}5}{\style{color:red}x}\;{\style{color:red}+}\;{\style{color:red}7})-({\style{color:blue}x}^{\style{color:blue}2}\;{\style{color:blue}-}\;{\style{color:blue}4}{\style{color:blue}x}\;{\style{color:blue}-}\;{\style{color:blue}3})\)

Step 2
Rewrite without the parentheses.
\((f-g)(x)=3x^2-5x+7-x^2-4x-3\)

Step 3
Put like terms together.
\((f-g)(x)=3x^2-x^2-5x+4x+7+3\)

Step 4
Combine like terms.
\((f-g)(x)=2x^2-x+10\)


  1. \((f-g)(x)=2x^2-x+10\)

Step 1
To find \((f-g)(-2)\), substitute \(x={\style{color:red}-}{\style{color:red}2}\).
\((f-g)( {\style{color:red}-}{\style{color:red}2})=2({\style{color:red}-}{\style{color:red}2})^2-({\style{color:red}-}{\style{color:red}2})+10\)

Step 2
Simplify.
\((f-g)(-2)=2 \cdot 5-(-2)+10\)
\((f-g)(-2)=20\)


Try It: Adding and Subtracting Polynomial Functions


For functions \(f(x)=2x^2-4x+3\) and \(g(x)=x^2-2x-6\), find:

  1. \((f+g)(x)\)
  2. \((f+g)(3)\)
  3. \((f-g)(x)\)
  4. \((f-g)(-2)\)

Write down your answers. Then select the Solution button to compare your work.

Here is how to add and subtract the polynomial functions:

  1. \(\begin{array}{rcl}(f+g)(x)&=&(2x^2-4x+3)+(x^2-2x-6)\\&=&2x^2-4x+3+x^2-2x-6\\&=&3x^2-6x-3\end{array}\)

  2. \(\begin{array}{rcl}(f+g)(3)&=&3(3)^2-6(3)-3\\&=&3(3)^2-6(3)-3\\&=&3(9)-18-3\\&=&6\end{array}\)

  3. \(\begin{array}{rcl}(f-g)(x)&=&(2x^2-4x+3)-(x^2-2x-6)\\&=&2x^2-4x+3-x^2+2x+6\\&=&x^2-2x+9\;\end{array}\)

  4. \(\begin{array}{rcl}(f-g)(-2)&=&(-2)^2-2(-2)+9\;\\&=&(4)+4+9\;\\&=&17\;\end{array}\)

answer.answer_text: I’d like to retry the self check.
I’m ready for the next activity.

page.title: 6.1.5: Reviewing Polynomial Addition and Subtraction
page.contents:
Cool Down Activity

Draw a tic-tac-toe board on an extra sheet of paper. Use the polynomial functions shown here for the activity.

\(f(x) = 8x^2-6x-2\)
\(h(x) = 6x^2-4x-1\)

For each polynomial problem below, place an \(X\) on your tic-tac-toe board corresponding to the location of its matching solution.

\(16x^2-9x^2 =\) ________
\((9x^2-5x-3)+(2x^2+8x-3) =\) ________
\(f(5) - h(-2) =\) ________
\((7x^2-3x+7)-(3x^2+6x-4) =\) ________
\(f(4) =\) ________

For each polynomial problem below, place an \(O\) on your tic-tac-toe board corresponding to the location of its matching solution.

\(11x^3+12x^3 =\) ________
\(f(x) - h(x) =\) ________
\(f(x) + h(x) =\) ________
\(h(-3) =\) ________


Did the \(Xs\) or \(Os\) win the tic-tac-toe game?

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

The \(Xs\) won the game.

Xs:

\(16x^2-9x^2 = 7x^2\)
\((9x^2-5x-3)+(2x^2+8x-3) = 11x^2+3x-6\)
\(f(5) - h(-2) = 137\)
\(f(4) = 102\)
\((7x^2-3x+7)-(3x^2+6x-4) = 4x^2-9x+11\)<\p>

Os:

\(11x^3+12x^3 = 23x^3\)
\(f(x) - h(x) = 2x^2-2x-1\)
\(f(x) + h(x) = 14x^2-10x-3\)
\(h(-3) = 65\)

page.title: 6.1.6: Practice
page.contents:
Complete the following questions to practice the skills you have learned in this lesson.

  1. \(14ab^2-8ab^2 =\) ________

Correct!

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 6.1.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is \(6ab^2\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. \(5xy^2+7xy^2 =\) ________

Correct!

Try again. Why don't you go back to activity 6.1.2 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is \(12xy^2\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. \((7b^2-2b-12)-(4b^2+9b-7) =\) ___________

Correct!

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 6.1.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is \(3b^2-11b-5\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. \( (7mn^3-2m^2n-12mn)-(3mn^3-4mn) =\) ___________

Correct!

Try again. Why don't you go back to activity 6.1.2 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is \(4mn^3-2m^2n-8mn\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. \( (r^3-r^2s)-2(rs^2+s^3)+(r^2s+2rs^2) =\) ___________

Correct!

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 6.1.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is \(r^3-2s^3\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

Use the following polynomial functions to answer questions 6–10.

  • \(p(x) = 12x^2+3x-4\)
  • \(d(x) = 3x^2-11x-6\)
  1. \( p(4) =\) ___________

Correct!

Try again. Why don't you go back to activity 6.1.3 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is 200. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. \(d(-3) =\) ___________

Correct!

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 6.1.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is 54. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. \(p(x) + d(x) =\) ___________

Correct!

Try again. Why don't you go back to activity 6.1.4 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is \(15x^2-8x-10\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. \(p(x) - d(x) =\) ___________

Correct!

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 6.1.4. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is \(9x^2+14x+2\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. \( p(5) - d(-6) =\) ___________

Correct!

Try again. Why don't you go back to activity 6.1.4 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is 143. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

page.title: 6.1.7: Lesson Summary
page.contents:
In this lesson, you learned how to:

  • Determine the degree of polynomials.
  • Add and subtract polynomials.
  • Evaluate a polynomial function for a given value.
  • Add and subtract polynomial functions.

Here are the activities that helped you reach those goals:

  • 6.1.1: Understanding Polynomials
    • In this activity, you classified different types of polynomials. You also found the degree of different polynomials.
  • 6.1.2: Adding and Subtracting Polynomials
    • In this activity, you added and subtracted different types of polynomials by grouping like terms.
    • 6.1.2: Self Check
    • 6.1.2: Additional Resources
  • 6.1.3: Evaluating a Polynomial Function for a Given Value
    • In this activity, you substituted given values into various polynomial functions and simplified to find solutions.
    • 6.1.3: Self Check
    • 6.1.3: Additional Resources
  • 6.1.4: Adding and Subtracting Polynomial Functions
    • In this activity, you used the skills learned in previous activities to add and subtract polynomial functions. You were able to check your work by evaluating the original and new polynomial functions using the same value.
    • 6.1.4: Self Check
    • 6.1.4: Additional Resources
  • 6.1.5: Reviewing Polynomial Addition and Subtraction
    • In this activity, you reviewed all of the skills you learned adding and subtracting polynomials to solve a tic-tac-toe puzzle.

After these activities, you completed the following practice:

  • 6.1.6: Practice

Checking In

On a scale of 1 to 5, how confident do you feel about the learning goals of this lesson?

Correct!

If you’ve answered 3 or less, be sure to reach out to your teacher before starting the next lesson.
